title: My Research
text:
Approximately 13% of the world’s population rely on coral reefs in some way, including for food security and nutrition (Sing Wong et al., 2022). At the same time, coral reef ecosystems are under immense pressure from overfishing, pollution, and climate change. While working for the Jesuit Justice and Ecology Network Africa in Nairobi, Kenya, I studied the relationship between fishery management, ecological function, and production of nutrients for human consumption in the artisanal coral reef fisheries of the Western Indian Ocean (Galligan, McClanahan, et al., 2022).

Sing Wong, A., Vrontos, S., & Taylor, M. L. (2022). An assessment of people living by coral reefs over space and time. Global Change Biology, 28(23), 7139–7153.

Galligan, B. P., McClanahan, T. R., & Humphries, A. T. (2022). Nutrient capture and sustainable yield maximized by a gear modification in artisanal fishing traps. Environmental Research Letters, 17(12), 124035.

title: My Research
section: Population dynamics of a commercially fished bivalve in Narragansett Bay
text:
Population dynamics of a commercially fished bivalve in Narragansett Bay
Northern quahogs (Mercenaria mercenaria) sustain a significant small-scale fishery, provide important ecosystem services, and are of great cultural importance in my home state of Rhode Island, U.S.A. However, as Narragansett Bay becomes more oligotrophic and experiences fewer episodes of hypoxia due to improved wastewater treatment and the effects of climate change, trophic relationships are changing in space and time. I collaborated with researchers at Loyola University Chicago and the Rhode Island Division of Marine Fisheries to study the impacts of these changes on Narragansett Bay quahogs and found evidence for a hypoxia-induced predation refuge that is becoming less influential as water quality improves (Galligan, Stuart, et al., 2022).

Galligan, B. P., Stuart, Y. E., McManus, M. C., & Stoffel, H. E. (2022). Hypoxia-induced predation refuge for northern quahogs (Mercenaria mercenaria) in a temperate estuary. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 265, 107732.

title: My Research
text:
Ecological justice for sustainable fisheries
As a Jesuit in formation to be a Catholic priest, I am deeply inspired by the thought of Pope Francis, who writes (2015, no. 139):

Francis. (2015). Laudato si’: Encyclical letter on care for our common home.

“We are faced not with two separate crises, one environmental and the other social, but rather with one complex crisis which is both social and environmental. Strategies for a solution demand an integrated approach to combating poverty, restoring dignity to the excluded, and at the same time protecting nature.”

My own “integrated approach” incorporates ethical reflection and advocacy alongside scientific research. It also influences what questions I choose to ask and how I seek to answer them (Zepeda & Galligan, 2023). While studying ethics at Loyola University Chicago, I developed a critique of international ocean governance that identified an extractivist paradigm in global fisheries (Galligan, 2021). More recently, I worked with a community on Kenya’s north coast to share their story of seeking remedy for human rights violations perpetrated by the government (Galligan & Kinney, 2021).

Zepeda, C. S., & Galligan, B. P. (2023). Integral ecology in research practice: Methodological insights for transformative change (Briefing Note No. 6). Laudato Si’ Research Institute, University of Oxford.

Galligan, B. P. (2021). Fisheries extractivism and the right to subsistence: Conflicting governance models and the legal structures that enact them. Marine Policy, 133, 104729.

Galligan, B. P., & Kinney, S. (2021). Providing access or taking sides? Blue growth, small-scale fisheries, and the case of Lamu, Kenya. Promotio Iustitiae, 132(2), 87–94.



The four pillars of integral ecology, summarizing Pope Francis in Laudato si’

title: Bryan P. Galligan, S.J.
text:
I am a Jesuit scholastic and marine ecologist interested in sustainable fisheries and ecological justice. Most of my work has focused on the intersection between fisheries and food security, including a significant emphasis on East African coral reefs. I have also worked on commercial fisheries in Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island, U.S.A., and am broadly interested in coastal ecosystem transitions due to climate change and other anthropogenic pressures, functional approaches to ecology and management, and achieving sustainable and just ocean governance.
To find out more about me and my work, explore this website and/or read my CV. To find out more about the Jesuits, including our training process and the types of work we do, click here.

title: Climate Change is “structural sin,” Bishops in Africa Say, Demand World Leaders’ Action
text:
Members of the Symposium of Episcopal Conference of Africa and Madagascar (SECAM) have joined other faith-based and civil society actors in demanding that world “decision makers” act fast to address the climate change crisis, which they say is a “striking example of structural sin.”
In a communiqué that the First Vice President of SECAM read out on Monday, October 17 on behalf of Catholic Bishops in Africa and members of the African Climate Dialogues steering committee, climate change was also described as “a moral outrage”, which has plunged many populations on the African continent into deep suffering.
Read the whole story here.

title: Bryan Galligan, SJ on Faith, Solidarity, White Saviorism, and Justice
text:
For this very special bonus episode, I am joined by Jesuit scholastic Bryan Galligan to discuss how his Catholic faith motivates his work in nutritional and social justice, how to move in solidarity while supporting community leadership and avoiding the pitfalls of white saviorism, and what faith traditions have to offer to the fight for seafood justice.
Listen to the full episode here.

title: Need for More Funds for Africa Emphasized at Jesuit Entity’s Workshop on Climate Justice
text:
The two-day strategy building workshop that brought together representatives of member and partner organizations of the Jesuit Justice and Ecology Network Africa (JENA) in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, this week to discuss climate justice and integral ecology emphasized the need for increasing funding for Africa.
In an interview with ACI Africa on the sidelines of the workshop that concluded Tuesday, June 14, JENA’s research and policy analyst for food and climate justice who organized the workshop said participants explored “the most important priorities for Africa for climate.”
“In this workshop, based on other dialogues, the most important priorities for Africa for climate right now are increased funding for adaptation,” Bryan P. Galligan told ACI Africa during the June 14 interview.
Read the whole story here.
